en:
A female figure, surrounded by ivy leaves, perhaps Eirene or Ge,
      standing 3/4-view to the right, with weight on her left leg, wearing a belted peplos, and long
      hair cascading over her shoulders, holds an infant, on a nebris, towards Hermes; the infant,
      perhaps Ploutos or Dionysos, wearing a himation, reclines 3/4-view to the left, on the nebris,
      but turns near profile to the right and reaches both arms up to Hermes; Hermes, advancing
      3/4-view to the left, with both legs bent, and his head bowed down, holds the child's right
      hand in his left hand, and his right hand on the child's head. He wears calf-length boots, a
      chlamys bucked in front, and a petasos. A kerykeion lies on the ground behind his right
      foot.

Beazley notes that this plate may have the same story shown on <rs
      type="vase">St. Petersburg St. 1792</rs>. It is impossible to determine how much of
      the drawing reflects restoration and/or artist's embellishments, as the vase is now lost. If
      the attributes are all authentic, then the identity of Hermes (with boots, chlamys, petasos,
      and kerykeion) is secure. As Dionysos is the baby who was traditionally handed to Hermes, and
      this baby is shown with nebris and ivy leaves, as befits Dionysos, it is most likely that he,
      not Ploutos, is here represented. Although she does not emerge from the ground, according to
      the drawing), the female figure is closer to the image of Ge (particularly on <rs
      type="vase">Naples H 2883</rs>, <rs type="vase">Istanbul 2576</rs> and
      <rs type="vase">St. Petersburg St. 1792</rs>) than the nymphs, who traditionally
      receive Dionysos, on account of her attire and hair.

J.H.W. Tischbein, <hi rend="ital">Collection of Engravings from Ancient
      Vases of Greek Workmanship Discovered in Sepulchres in the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies but
      Chiefly in the Neighbourhood of Naples during the Course of the Years MDCCLXXXIX and MDCCLXXXX
      Now in the Possession of Sir. Wm. Hamilton</hi> (Naples 1795) 3.14-15, pl.
      8.
